To apply this in your crypto investments:

1. Ensure every investment has homerun potential
2. Cultivate a short memory and remember that bets going to 0 is just part of the game. 

Hope that is helpful!

VC in a nutshell: hit home runs or don‚Äôt play the game. 

Crypto is not very different. It just moves faster. 

In fact, Multicoin‚Äôs historic performance has really been driven by a select few homeruns (Solana, Helium).

At a rough minimum, VCs must target investments with a 25%+ chance of becoming a 10x+ investment in 3 years. 

The upside is not capped. 

Example below: https://t.co/hP5IpEi7Pb

More at-bats is simple. The few winners make up for the many losers. 

Higher-quality at-bats is more complex. 

The best do it by:

1. Backing the right teams in the right markets at the right times
2. Helping those teams achieve their milestones.

The key to winning in VC is thus to hit home runs.

There are two strategies to accomplish this:

1. More at-bats 
2. Higher quality at-bats.
But the best VC funds also have the most, and biggest, home runs. https://t.co/XUSqecQo2r
The best VC funds (5x+) actually have more strikeouts than good funds (2-5x). https://t.co/kfKHDjwhgX

VC is a game of home runs. 

It is driven by two important concepts:

1. Failed investments don‚Äôt matter (that much)
2. Every investment must have home run potential.

VC returns follow a power-law distribution. 

In other words, most returns come from a small number of investments. 

This is also called asymmetry. https://t.co/MXJmF8Tz7N

In crypto, we are operating in a world where ‚Äúeverybody is a VC.‚Äù

Protocol tokens are like startup equity - just more liquid and volatile.

In order to be a great crypto investor, you must understand the game of VC.

Crypto investors love hating on VCs. 

But they are more alike than you think.  

So how does VC really work? 

And how can it make you a better crypto investor?

The key to managing risk is simple:

1. Be defensive when the market is hot
2. Be aggressive when the market is cold.

In Buffet terminology: "be fearful when others are greedy and greedy when others are fearful."

When the market is hot (like today), investors:
- Become risk tolerant 
- Demand lower risk premiums (buy at higher prices).

When the market is cold (like post-2008), investors:
- Become risk adverse 
- Demand higher risk premiums (buy at lower prices).

Attitudes toward risk can be captured by the Capital Market Line (CML).

As you take on more risk, your required return is higher:

- In good times, the curve gets flatter
- In bad times, the curve gets steeper. https://t.co/VJcEVVfBUi

Risk IS NOT volatility (how much and how fast prices change). 

Risk IS:

1. Permanent loss of capital (in bad times)
2. Fear of missing out (in good times).

To be a great investor, especially in today's markets, you must understand risk. 

A short primer on risk:

The Simple Path to Build Conviction:

1. Write an investment thesis

2. Make it simple, clear, and no longer than one paragraph

3. If/when prices drop, go back to this thesis

4. If the thesis still stands, HODL

5. Rinse and repeat.

@rabois Very contrarian ser.

3/ Practically, investing is dealing with the price of assets, determining where they are today, and making judgements as to where they will be in the future (calculating intrinsic value).

You buy when: price < intrinsic value. 

You sell when: price > intrinsic value.

2/ Conceptually, investing is placing money in a storehold of wealth (assets) that converts to buying power in the future.

You give a lump sum today for lump sums tomorrow. 

Money matters least. Buying power (the amount of goods and services you get for money) matters most.

1/ Intellectually, investing is the act of expressing your insight about the future.

If you are right, you are economically rewarded (resources gained).

If you are wrong, you are economically punished (resources lost).
3 Definitions of Investing:

The 3 biggest mistakes any investor can make:

1. Speculating when you think you are investing
2. Risking more money than you can afford to lose
3. Trying to predict the macroeconomy.
